MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000174
Special Investigation Intake Date: December 5, 2024
License #: CB820315857
Licensee Group Organization: Community Care Organization
Licensee Designee: Kendra Washington
Chief Administrator: Darnell Britt
Agency Name: Community Care Organization
Agency Address: 18688 Joann St
Detroit, MI 48205-2748
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/28/2026

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry.
Description (3) An agency's policy on staff qualifications must state all
the following:
(b) A person who is listed on the central registry as a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect is
ineligible for employment if the responsibilities of the
position includes unsupervised contact with children.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation It is alleged that an agency staff member is on central registry.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 12/05/24.
Complainant stated that a staff person, hereafter referred to as
Person 1, is on Central Registry and works in the agency office.
Complainant reported Person 1 visits the agency independent
living homes.
The Program Manager was interviewed via telephone on
12/13/2024. Program Manager reported that Person 1 is not on
central registry and does not work under the agency foster care
license. Program Manager reported Person 1, when employed
under the foster care license, was investigated but reiterated that
he is not on central registry. Program Manager reported Person 1
is an employee of Community Care Organization but works under
a contract the agency has with DTE Energy. Program Manager
denies that Person 1 has visited the independent living homes
since his investigation and has no interaction or contact with youth
involved with the agency.
Person 1 was interviewed on 03/24/2025. Person 1 reported
that he works for Community Care Organization under the DTE
Energy contract. Person 1 reported he has not visited the
independent living homes since 2023 when he was investigated.
Person 1 reported he has office space at 22001 Kelly Road in
Eastpointe. Person 1 explained his office is in a portion of the
building that is not used by staff under the foster care license or by
youth served by the agency. Person 1 reported his job with DTE
involves helping people to obtain services for their homes.
Interviews with Youth E, Youth F, Youth G, Youth H, and
Youth I were conducted on 03/26/2025 and all deny that they
2

know Person 1 or that Person 1 visited their independent living
homes.
Chief Administrator was interviewed on 3/25/2025. He reported
Person 1 does not have any interaction with agency foster care
staff under the license nor have interactions with youth. He
explained Person 1 is not a part of any of the licensed programs
with the agency and works under the DTE contract to assist
homes in becoming energy efficient.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• A MDHHS letter to Person 1 dated 11/01/2024 indicates
that Person 1 is not listed as being on Central Registry.
• A MDHHS document dated 01/12/205 to Person 1 states in
part that Person 1’s case history is a barrier to employment.
• The address to the license does not match Person 1’s
office address.
Analysis The Program Manager denies that Person 1 is on Central Registry
and he is not working under the agency foster care license. The
Program Manager denies that Person 1 has visited the
independent living homes. Person 1 denies that he works under
the agency foster care license and further denies that he has
visited the independent living homes since 2023.
Youth E, F, G, H, and Youth I reported that they do not know
Person 1. Documentation reviewed indicates that Person 1 is not
on Central Registry.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry.
Description • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation It is alleged that staff are drinking and using substances. It is
further alleged that staff are withholding youth’s money and using
it for themselves.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on 12/06/2024 and reported that
agency staff are drinking alcohol and smoking marijuana outside
of the office building at 19992 Kelly Rd. The Complainant
3

specifically reported that Person 1 and Program Manager are
using drugs.
Program Manager was interviewed on 12/13/2024 and
03/24/2025 and denied that she, Person 1, or any other staff are
using drugs or drinking alcohol at the offices. Program Manager
reported Chief Administrator works from home and is not at the
office. Program Manager reported there are staff that provide
supervision at the ILP homes and other office staff, Staff 1, works
from her home in Houston, Texas. Program Manager denied that
staff are using youth’s stipend or bridge cards for their own
personal use.
Person 1 was interviewed on 03/25/2025 and stated that “it’s a
bold faced lie” that he is using drugs or drinking at the office. His
office is not housed in the office space occupied by programs
regulated by the Department of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL)
and he does not visit the ILP homes.
Youth A was interviewed via video on 02/04/2025. Youth A
reported that she has been a resident of the independent living
program since 2023. Youth A reported she denies ever seeing
staff using substances and she feels safe at the program. Youth A
reports that her bridge card is loaded with $241 every month.
Youth A reports she receives $209 every two weeks after rent is
paid. Youth A reports she has no complaints about the program.
Youth B was interviewed via video on 02/02/2025. Youth B
stated, “it’s good here.” Youth B reported she gets a $209 check
every two weeks and she has a bridge card that she uses. Youth
B reports she trusts the staff and feels safe at the program. Youth
B denied she has ever observed staff drinking or using drugs at
the program.
Youth C was interviewed via video on 02/04/2025. Youth C
reported she receives $209 every two weeks and has a bridge
card. Youth C reported she receives $125 dollars per month in
food stamps. Youth C reported she feels safe at the program and
never has smelled alcohol or marijuana on any of the staff.
Youth D was interviewed via video on 02/04/2025. Youth D
reported that he receives $209 every two weeks. Youth D reported
that he also gets $292 per month on his bridge card. Youth D
reported he gets all the money he is supposed to receive. Youth D
reported staff treat him with respect, and he feels safe at the
4

program. Youth D reported that he has never seen staff using
drugs or drinking alcohol.
Youth E was interviewed via video on 03/26/2025. Youth E
reported she receives $200 every two weeks. Youth E reported
staff are working to get her a bridge card. Youth E reported she
feels safe at the program, and she has not seen staff using drugs
or alcohol.
Youth F was interviewed via video on 03/26/2025. Youth F
reported that staff at the program are “nice” and treat him with
respect. Youth F reports he gets his $209 check every two weeks.
Youth F also reported that he has a bridge card. Youth F denied
observing staff using drugs or drinking alcohol.
Youth G was interviewed on 03/26/2025 via video. Youth G
reports he receives his $209 check every two weeks and has a
bridge card. Youth G reported he feels safe at the program and
has never seen staff using drugs or alcohol.
Youth H was interviewed via video on 03/26/2025.Youth H
reported he receives $209 every two weeks. Youth H reported
Program Manager is working on getting him a bridge card. Youth
H reported he feels safe at the program. Youth H reported he has
never seen staff using drugs or alcohol.
Youth I was interviewed via video on 03/26/2025. Youth I
reported she receives her $209 check every two weeks and
currently Program Manager is working to get her a bridge card.
Youth I reported staff at the program are “amazing” and she feels
safe.
Program Manager was interviewed briefly again on 03/26/2025
via video. Program Manager reported the bridge cards for Youth
E, Youth H, and Youth I keep getting denied. Program Manager
reported that a liaison is involved to resolve the issue.
Analysis The Program Manager and Person 1 deny using drugs or alcohol
at the offices or programs. Youth A through Youth I report that
they have never observed staff using drugs or alcohol. All the
youth report feeling safe at the program.
The Program Manager denied that staff are withholding youth’s
money and using it for their own use.
5

Youth A through Youth I reported that they receive their allotted
stipend. All youth except Youth E, H, and Youth I have bridge
cards. The Program Manager reported she is working on obtaining
bridge cards for the aforementioned youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
Section • (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by
Description the child placing agency, must be clean, safe, and
appropriate to the needs of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that youth living arrangements are not safe.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on 12/06/2024 and reported the
independent living home at 18688 Joanne and 4826/4828
Lakewood are filthy and cockroach invested. Complainant
reported the living conditions are unsafe as a result.
Program Manager was interviewed on 12/13/2024 and reported
the homes did have cockroaches but the homes are being treated
by an extermination company. Program Manager stated she
would send receipts of the extermination treatments as requested
by this consultant.
Interviews with Youth E, Youth F, Youth G, Youth H, and
Youth I were conducted on 03/26/2025. Each reported that there
are no cockroaches in the homes and are insect free. All youth
reported the home they live in is clean.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• Consultant 1 completed an unannounced visit to the
independent living homes on 1/08/2025. Consultant 1
presented via email a detailed description of each of the
visits of the homes. Consultant 1 reported during her visit to
the 4826/4828 Lakewood visit she walked through the
entire home, and this included looking in cabinets,
refrigerators and bathrooms. There was no observed
cockroaches or insects. Consultant 1 reported two youths
she encountered in the home reported the home was
treated a couple of weeks ago. Consultant 1 reported there
were no concerns with the home. Consultant 1 reported her
visit to the 18688 Joanne home did not cause any concerns
6

about the home. Consultant 1 reported she walked through
the upstairs and downstairs as well as the entrance to the
basement. No cockroaches or insects were observed.
• L and I Contracting and Property Management Co. Pest
control receipts indicated that three pest control
applications were conducted at the Lakewood and Joanne
homes from January through March 2024, three
applications from April through June 2024, three
applications from July to September 2024, and three
applications from October to December 2024.
Analysis Youth A through Youth I report living in a clean environment and
no cockroach infestations were reported.
Consultant 1 reported that she did not observe cockroaches or
other pests during her unannounced visits to the homes.
Consultant 1 reported that there were no concerns noted during
her visits.
Pest control documents indicate the homes have been treated
throughout the year 2024.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
4/22/2025
______________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
4/22/2025

Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
